text: So imagine, for example, we sell an option on emerging market equities, say, some Chinese stock or say Alibaba. Alibaba probably trades in Hong Kong. It's trading in New York, but also in Hong Kong. So the problem is that if the size of your trade is very big, and if, let's say, imagine we just sold straddle. So we sold put and we sold call. So initially our delta is about zero. But then something happened. So just for example, it's ADR. It trades in New York. But imagine overnight there was some tweet from Trump that Hong Kong is deeply down. And given the size of your position, if you want to hedge, rebalance your delta, which say the stock tanked, you need to say buy whatever, 10 million shares. You know that if you put your order in the market, you are going to move it. It's already moved a lot. And then you are going to proportionally to your hedging needs, you are going to move a lot. And it creates this cyclical feedback loop. And it's a big problem. For less liquid markets where you trade in big notionals, it's a problem. And effectively it tells you that, say, originally the trade could be good. Say you sell. I think implied at 30 and you expect it realizes at 20. And in option trading is relatively good trade. But if during the hedging, you're say volatility cost is 20%, so you lost money. And you lost money not because the realized volatility can still realize at 20, but because you cost, it was you who created this volatility. It cost you a lot to sell. It cost you a lot to hedge. This is one example. Another example is gap risk. For example, let's say again, this ADR. Maybe this time you don't have big notionals, but imagine end of day, you are delta neutral. But every time there is something going on in China. And every night the stock gaps 4%, or say 2-3%, which you cannot hedge. So every time you will lose this 2-3% gap risk. So in the end, it's again close to close volatility can be relatively small and will not cause you a problem. But if you hedge every gap, you will bleed gamma. To say that, and therefore from beginning, it's not only enough to look at say, what is my expected spread? You need to look also, what was my contingency plan? If something goes wrong, or I need to hedge a big chunk of it. What is my expected cost? So therefore, what I like in this, say, hedging is must be quantitative. And the output of your model is not only the fair value in ideal conditions, but also adverse. You need to account for adverse conditions.
